SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, uising terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Read these sentences from paragraphs 13 and 17 of the story.

:box:She wrote: The Case of the Big Stink.

Inez wrote: Plan 1: Sniff out the stink.
Which best describes why these lines are important to the story?

A.Choice: They show how the girls record their information.

B.Choice: They provide proof that Inez has the best ideas.

C.Choice: They give a clue that the story is about a dog.

D.Choice: They show that Inez wants to be a writer.

SubTopics: Ask and answe questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: In the story, which two items smell the same?

A.Choice: the curtains and the garbage can

SubTopics: Ask and answe questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: In paragraphs 27 and 28, why does Izzy think the clue is important?

A.Choice: It shows why the smelly things are in the house.

B.Choice: It shows a way to connect all of the smelly things.

C.Choice: It shows that the girls need to look for more things that smell the same.

D.Choice: It shows that the girls have become good at finding the things that smell.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 45 of the story.
:box:“Check out the area behind these bushes,” said Izzy.
Which best describes the meaning of “check out” as it is used in the sentence?

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral  and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Which best describes the main idea of the story?

A.Choice: Three girls write in their notebook about a smelly dog.

B.Choice: Three girls try to discover where a bad smell comes from.

C.Choice: Three girls discover that some parts of the house are smelly.

D.Choice: Three girls help look for things in the house that smell the same.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Why do the girls most likely call themselves the “Private I's”?

A.Choice: because they want to keep a big secret

B.Choice: because they keep their information in a notebook

C.Choice: because they are all important and because of their ideas

D.Choice: because they are solving a mystery and because of their names

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral  and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Mary Jane is bringing her art project to school that day.

B.Choice: Mary Jane notices that her art leftovers are gone from the table.

C.Choice: Mary Jane thanks her mother for cleaning the table.

D.Choice: Mary Jane plans to eat some eggs and bacon for breakfast

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, uising terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: Why is paragraph 17 important to the rest of the story?

A.Choice: It introduces Smokey's favorite piece of furniture.

B.Choice: It introduces a conflict between Josh and his mother.

C.Choice: It suggests that Josh knows where Smokey hides.

D.Choice: It gives the information that helps Mary Jane solve the problem.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Read these sentences from paragraph 19.
:box:She hopped out of her seat and ran into the next room. With a grunt, she slowly pulled out the heavy chair.
Which words give the best clue for why Mary Jane grunts?

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: What does paragraph 2 mostly show about Mary Jane?

D.Choice: She spends a lot of time on her assignments.

Content: What did Mary Jane make for her art project?

A.Choice: a sheet of glass with colored tissue paper

B.Choice: a fancy window with ice pop sticks and colored tissue paper

C.Choice: a tiny home with ice pop sticks and colored tissue paper

D.Choice: a bed frame with ice pop sticks

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 11.
:box:Yet they had drawbacks, too.
The word “drawbacks” shows that the electric car

A.Choice: was not quickly accepted by the public

B.Choice: changed the way that people traveled

C.Choice: did not provide a perfect solution

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: How do paragraphs 10 through 15 support a main idea of the passage?

A.Choice: by discussing how several inventors improved cars

B.Choice: by listing the names of countries to show how far apart they are

C.Choice: by describing the condition of the streets to show the need for better roads

D.Choice: by showing that drivers had to be stopped because their cars were going too fast

Content: How are paragraphs 14 through 17 connected?

A.Choice: They show a problem that existed and explain how Henry Ford solved it.

B.Choice: They describe the order of steps to move a Model T from the factory to the roads.

C.Choice: They compare the number of parts in a Model T to the number of parts in other cars.

D.Choice: They explain the effect of typical earnings on the people who worked for Henry Ford.

Content: Read these paragraphs from the story.

:box:“E-e-e-w, what stinks?” Mary exclaimed. (paragraph 1)

“E-e-e-w, what stinks?” Mary asked again. Her shoe accidentally crushed a plant. The smell made tears come to her eyes. (paragraph 19)
Why does the author repeat “E-e-e-w, what stinks?” in paragraphs 1 and 19? Use two details from the story to support your response.
